choices.text: Defect in SGLT 1 in renal tubule
Increase excretion of excess glucose in urine due to bacterial infection.
Decrease ability of glucose to reabsorb due to defect in SGLT 2 in renal tubule
Increase absorption in intestine leads to increase secretion in urine.

questions.text: A 33 year old female presented to the clinic with the complaint of frequent urination and burning during micturition. She revealed that she had been repeatedly suffering from these problems. Urine analysis revealed glycosuria. Fasting blood glucose and HbA1c were with in normal range. So what is the defect in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Urinary glucose with normal fasting blood glucose along with normal HbA1c indicates this is a case of renal glycosuria. Urinary tract infection is a possibility in this case and must be investigated with urine culture.
  • Renal glycosuria is caused due to decrease ability of kidneys to reabsorb filtered glucose in proximal tubule due to defect in sodium dependent glucose transporter (SGLT 2).
    • The high glucose in urine predisposes the individual to frequent urinary tract infection.

Reference: Harper's, 32nd edition, Page no. 597

choices.text: Inhibit electron transport via Complex I by blocking the transfer from Fe-S to Q
Inhibit oxidative phosphorylation by inhibiting the transporter of ADP into and ATP out of the mitochondrion

questions.text: Barbiturates at very high dosage is fatal, because it inhibits electron transport chain. Which of the following is mechanism of action of Barbiturate?
questions.solution:
Inhibitors of respiratory chain provided knowledge about the mechanism of action of several poisons. They may be classified as inhibitors of the respiratory chain, inhibitors of oxidative phosphorylation, or uncouplers of oxidative phosphorylation.

Option A: Barbiturates such as amobarbital inhibit electron transport via Complex I by blocking the transfer from Fe-S to Q. At sufficient high dosage, they are fatal.

Option B: Cytochrome oxidase is complex IV of ETC. Inhibitor of cytochrome oxidase are H2S, carbon monoxide, and cyanide.

Option C: Uncouplers dissociate oxidation in the respiratory chain from phosphorylation. The uncoupler that has been used most frequently is 2,4-dinitrophenol. Thermogenin is a physiologic uncoupler found in brown adipose tissue that functions to generate body heat, particularly for the newborn and during hibernation in animals.

Option D: Atractyloside inhibits oxidative phosphorylation by inhibiting the transporter of ADP into and ATP out of the mitochondrion.

The antibiotic oligomycin also completely blocks oxidation and phosphorylation by blocking the flow of protons through ATP synthase.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry, 32nd edition, Ch 13, Pg 123

questions.text: Regarding glucose transporters [GLUT], incorrect match is:
questions.solution: Reference: Harper's, 32nd edition, Page no.191

choices.text: Most but not all GAGs contain an amino sugar and a uronic acid.
GAGs are built up by the actions of glycosyltransferases using sugars donated by nucleotide-sugars.
Glucuronic acid can be converted to iduronic acid by an epimerase.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about mucopolysaccharides except:
questions.solution:
Hyaluronic acid (hyaluronan) is does not contain any sulfate group.

  • There are at least seven GAGs: hyaluronic acid (hyaluronan), chondroitin sulfate, keratan sulfates I and II, heparin, heparan sulfate, and dermatan sulfate.
  • GAGs are unbranched polysaccharides made up of repeating disaccharides, one component of which is always an amino sugar (hence, the name GAG), either d-glucosamine or d-galactosamine. The other component of the repeating disaccharide (except in the case of keratin sulfate) is a uronic acid, either l-glucuronic acid (GlcUA) or its 5'-epimer, l-iduronic acid (IdUA). With the exception of hyaluronic acid, all the GAGs contain sulfate groups, either as O-esters or as N-sulfate (in heparin and heparan sulfate).
  • Hyaluronic acid is also exceptional because it appears to exist as a polysaccharide in the ECM, with no covalent attachment to protein, as the definition of a proteoglycan given above specifies.

Reference: Harper's, 32nd edition, Page no. 634-635

questions.text: All of the following occurs during fasting state except:
questions.solution:
On Decreasing Blood Glucose Level, glucagon is released from β cells of Pancreas.

  • Fructose 2, 6-bisphosphate is formed by phosphorylation of fructose-6-phosphate by phosphofructokinase-2.
  • The same enzyme protein is also responsible for its breakdown, since it has fructose 2, 6-bisphosphatase
  • This bifunctional enzyme is under the allosteric control of fructose-6-phosphate, which stimulates the kinase and inhibits the phosphatase.
  • Hence, when there is an abundant supply of glucose, the concentration of fructose 2, 6-bisphosphate increases, stimulating glycolysis by activating phosphofructokinase-1 and inhibiting fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase.
  • In the fasting state, glucagon stimulates the production of cAMP, activating cAMP-dependent protein kinase, which in turn inactivates phosphofructokinase-2 and activates fructose 2, 6-bisphosphatase by phosphorylation.
  • Hence, gluconeogenesis is stimulated by a decrease in the concentration of fructose 2, 6-bisphosphate, which inactivates phosphofructokinase-1 and relieves the inhibition of fructose 1, 6-bisphosphatase. Increases the Blood Glucose Level by Inhibiting By phosphorylating the key enzymes of Glycolysis
  • By decreasing the level of Fructose 2, 6 Bisphosphate, the product of PFK-II
  • Favor Gluconeogenesis
  • By phosphorylating Key enzymes of Gluconeogenesis
  • By favoring Fructose 2, 6 Bisphosphatase, which decreases the level of Fructose 2, 6 Bisphosphate, a potent activator of PFK-I.

Reference: Harper's, 32nd edition, Page no.189

questions.text: A 43 year old man presented with symptoms of weakness, fatigue, shortness of breath, and dizziness. His hemoglobin levels were between 5 to 7 g/dl (normal for male being greater than 13.5 g/dl). Red blood cells isolated from the patient showed abnormally low level of lactate production. A deficiency of which one of the following enzymes would be the most likely cause of this patient's anemia?
questions.solution:
• Pyruvate kinase deficiency: The normal, mature erythrocyte lacks mitochondria and is, therefore, completely dependent on glycolysis for production of ATP. This high-energy compound is required to meet the metabolic needs of the red blood cell, and also to fuel the pumps necessary for the maintenance of the bi-concave, flexible shape of the cell, which allows it to squeeze through narrow capillaries.
  • The anemia observed in glycolytic enzyme deficiencies is a consequence of the reduced rate of glycolysis, leading to decreased ATP production. The resulting alterations in the red blood cell membrane lead to changes in the shape of the cell and, ultimately, to phagocytosis by the cells of the reticuloendothelial system, particularly macrophages of the spleen. The premature death and lysis of the red blood cell result in hemolytic anemia.
  • Among patients exhibiting genetic defects of glycolytic enzymes, about 95 percent show a deficiency in pyruvate kinase, and four percent exhibit Phosphoglucose/hexose isomerase deficiency.
  • Pyruvate kinase (PK) deficiency is the second most common cause (after dehydrogenase deficiency) of enzymatic-related hemolytic anemia. PK deficiency is restricted to the erythrocytes, and produces mild to severe chronic hemolytic anemia(erythrocyte destruction), with the severe form requiring regular cell transfusions.

Reference: Lippincoatt SAE/Page no.198-199

questions.text: Carboxylation of clotting factors by vitamin K is required to be biologically active. Which of the following amino acid is carboxylated?
questions.solution:
Vitamin K is the cofactor for the carboxylation of glutamate residues in the postsynthetic modification of proteins to form the unusual amino acid γ-carboxyglutamate (Gla).

Initially, vitamin K hydroquinone is oxidized to the epoxide, which activates a glutamate residue, which reacts nonenzymically with carbon dioxide to form γ-carboxyglutamate.

Vitamin K epoxide is reduced to the quinone by a warfarin-sensitive reductase, and the quinone is reduced to the active hydroquinone by either the same warfarin-sensitive reductase or a warfarin-insensitive quinone reductase.

The proteins that are gamma carboxylated by vitamin K are:

  • Clotting factors II, VII, IX, X
  • Protein C, Protein S
  • Osteocalcin, Nephrocalcin
  • Product of gene gas 6

γ-Carboxyglutamate chelates calcium ions, and so permits the binding of the blood-clotting proteins to membranes.

  • The vitamin that act as coenzyme for carboxylation is biotin.
  • The vitamin that act as coenzyme for gamma carboxylation is vitamin K.

Reference: Harper's 32nd edition, page 555, 717

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy admitted with failure to thrive with high glutamine and uracil in urine, hypoglycemia, and high blood ammonia levels. Treatment was given for 2 months. At 8 months of age, he was admitted again for failure to gain weight. Gastric tube feeding was not tolerated and the child became comatose. Parenteral dextrose given. Child recovered from coma within 24 hours. What is the enzyme defect?
questions.solution:
In the given case, there is deficiency of Ornithine transcarbamoylase (OTC) enzyme and for that the clue to diagnosis is:

  • High glutamine: Usually seen in hyperammonemia.
  • Increased uracil in urine can be seen in OTC defect because as OTC is defective, carbamoyl phosphate in mitochondria spills to cytoplasm. Then it enters into pyrimidine synthesis. Pyrimidine intermediates and pyrimidines can accumulate. Hence, uracil is present in urine.

Hyperammonemia Type II (OTC Deficiency)

  • Most common urea cycle disorder.
  • Disorder with X-linked partially dominant inheritance (All other urea cycle disorders are Autosomal Recessive).
  • Urea cycle disorder with orotic aciduria
  • Marked elevations of plasma concentrations of glutamine and alanine with low levels of citrulline and arginine
  • Orotate may precipitate in urine as a pink colored gravel or stones.

Reference: Harper's, 32nd edition, page 295

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with progressive palmoplantar pigmentation. X-ray spine shows calcification of IV disk. On adding Benedict's reagent to urine, it gives greenish brown precipitate and blue-black supernatant fluid. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Alkaptonuria. It is an autosomal recessive inborn error of metabolism.

Biochemical defect - Homogentisate Oxidase deficiency leads to accumulation of Homogentisic Acid (Homogentisate) which polymerises to form Alkaptone bodies.

Clinical presentation:

  • Normal Life till 3rd or 4th decade.
  • Urine darkens on exposure to air is the only manifestation in children.
  • In adults Ochronosis: Alkaptone bodies in intervertebral disk, cartilage of nose, pinna etc.
  • No mental retardation

Laboratory Diagnosis:

  • Alkalization increase darkening of urine.
  • Benedicts test positive in urine because homogentisic acid is reducing agent.
  • Ferric Chloride test positive.
  • Silver Nitrate Test positive.

Treatment - Symptomatic treatment

Reference: Harper's, 32nd edition, page 304

questions.text: Match the apoprotein with the lipoprotein:
questions.solution:
The apoproteins present in the lipoproteins are as follows:

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry, 32nd edition, page 694; Nelson textbook of pediatrics, Page no 585

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic male presented with acute pain in upper abdomen that radiate to back along with fever and sever vomiting. A treating physician suspect acute pancreatitis. Which of following plasma enzyme level will be specifically increased in acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Option A: In acute pancreatitis, the plasma activity of amylase is increased, although in mild cases it may be normal, as amylase is small enough to be filtered at glomerulus and secreted in the urine. Plasma amylase is also increased in salivary glands diseases also as it is produced by salivary gland also, so not specific for pancreatitis.

Option B: Serum lipase is specifically elevated only in acute pancreatitis.

Option C: The activities of serum alanine (ALT) and aspartate (AST) aminotransferases are significantly elevated in hepatocellular injury as in case of acute viral hepatitis. ALT is considered to be more specific for liver disease than AST, because AST is elevated in cases of cardiac or skeletal muscle injury while ALT is not.

Option D: Serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) activity is elevated in obstructive jaundice. A high activity of serum alkaline phosphatase is also seen in bone disease.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry, 32nd edition, Ch 48, Pg 567

questions.text: Which of the following LDH is having fastest electrophoretic mobility?
questions.solution:
• LDH having fastest electrophoretic mobility is LDH-1
  • LDH having least electrophoretic mobility is LDH-5
  • Creatine Kinase having fastest electrophoretic mobility is CK-1
  • Creatine Kinase having least electrophoretic mobility is CK-3.

Reference: Harper's, 32nd edition, page 69

questions.text: Statin is a lipid lowering drug. Statin drug act by which of the following inhibition mechanisms on HMG CoA reductase?
questions.solution:
Acetoacetyl-CoA condenses with a further molecule of acetyl-CoA catalyzed by HMG-CoA synthase to form HMG-CoA, which is reduced to mevalonate by NADPH in a reaction catalyzed by HMG-CoA reductase. This last step is the principal regulatory step in the pathway of cholesterol synthesis and is the site of action of the most effective class of cholesterol-lowering drugs, the statins, which are HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors.

The statin drugs that act as competitive inhibitors of HMGCoA reductase have Ki values several orders of magnitude lower than the Km for the substrate, HMG-CoA.

Reference: Harper's, 32nd edition, page 267,82.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male having problem of infertility and chronic respiratory infection. He was probably diagnosed to have Kartagener syndrome after many biochemical investigations. A mutation in the genes affecting synthesis of which of the following protein which involved in movement of cilia and flagella, have been detected in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Microtubules are in a state of dynamic instability, constantly assembling and disassembling.
  • They exhibit polarity (plus and minus ends); a feature important to both in their growth from centrioles and their ability to direct intracellular movement.
  • For instance, in axonal transport, the protein kinesin, with a myosin-like ATPase activity, uses hydrolysis of ATP to move vesicles down the axon toward the positive end of the microtubular formation.
  • Flow of materials in the opposite direction, toward the negative end, is powered by cytosolic dynein, another protein with ATPase activity.
  • Similarly, axonemal dyneins power ciliary and flagellar movement while dynamin, which uses GTP instead of ATP, is involved in endocytosis.
  • An absence of dynein in cilia and flagella results in immotile cilia and flagella, leading to male sterility, situs inversus, and chronic respiratory infection, a condition known as Kartagener syndrome. Mutations in genes affecting the synthesis of dynein have been detected in individuals with this syndrome.

So, option C is correct.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry, 32nd edition, Ch 51, Pg 625

questions.text: A 54-year-old male, presented with abdominal pain & jaundice. Ultrasound abdomen shows a stone in the biliary tract. Which of the following vitamin injections should be given before doing any surgical procedure to this patient to avoid excess bleeding?
questions.solution:
• This is case of obstructive jaundice due to biliary tract stone. Due to the absence of bile, lipid and all lipid soluble vitamin are not absorbed properly. Hence, it leads to a deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins (Vitamin A, D, E, K).
  • This patient is prone for Vitamin K deficiency.
  • Vitamin K is required for clotting of blood. Vitamin injection should be given before doing any surgical procedure to this patient to avoid excess bleeding

Option A: Vitamin D is fat soluble vitamin. Its deficiency may be seen in this patient, but no role in clotting.

Option B: Vitamin K is fat soluble vitamin and required for clotting of blood. Vitamin injection should be given before doing any surgical procedure to this patient to avoid excess bleeding

Option C: Vitamin C is water soluble vitamin. Its absorption not impaired in fat malabsorption. Although vitamin C deficiency can lead to bleeding due to fragile vessels due to improper formation of collagen.

Option D: Vitamin B12 is water soluble vitamin. Its absorption not impaired in fat malabsorption.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry, 32nd edition, Ch 44, Pg 527

questions.text: Vitamin B6 act as coenzyme for which one of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Option A: Glycogen synthase does not require vitamin B6.

Option B:

  • Pyridoxal phosphate is a coenzyme for glycogen phosphorylase, where the phosphate group is catalytically important.
  • The active coenzyme form of vitamin B6 is pyridoxal 5'-phosphate.
  • Pyridoxal phosphate also act as a coenzyme for many enzymes involved in amino acid metabolism, especially transamination and decarboxylation.

Option C:

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase is multienzyme complex, which convert pyruvate to acetyl CoA (oxidation of pyruvate).
  • It requires many vitamins as coenzymes like thiamine diphosphate (Vitamin B1), coenzyme A (Vitamin B5), FAD (riboflavin, vitamin B2), NAD (Niacin, vitamin B3), lipoate.
  • But it will not require vitamin B6.

Option D:

  • Alpha keto glutarate dehydrogenase is also a multienzyme complex similar to Pyruvate dehydrogenase.
  • It converts alpha keto glutarate to succinyl CoA in citric acid cycle.
  • It also requires many vitamins as coenzymes similar to Pyruvate dehydrogenase like thiamine diphosphate (Vitamin B1), coenzyme A (Vitamin B5), FAD (riboflavin, vitamin B2), NAD (Niacin, vitamin B3), lipoate. But it will not require vitamin B6.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry, 32nd edition, Ch 44, Pg 535

questions.text: Keshan disease is a cardiomyopathy, first identified in China. It occurs as due to eating of food produced from soil deficient of which of the following minerals?
questions.solution:
Option A:

  • Zinc deficiency can lead to Acrodermatitis enteropathica.
  • Zinc Deficiency can also lead to stunted growth in children, loss of taste sensation, poor wound healing, skin lesions (hyperkeratosis, dermatitis), alopecia, impaired spermatogenesis seen.
  • It can also lead to depression, dementia and other psychiatric disorders.
  • Acrodermatitis Enteropathica: Genetic condition where zinc absorption is defective which lead to zinc deficiency.
    • It is characterized by acrodermatitis (inflammation around mouth, nose, fingers etc), diarrhoea, alopecia (loss of hair in discrete areas), ophthalmoplegia and hypogonadism

Option B:

  • Selenium deficiency can lead to Keshan disease.
  • It is prevalent in Keshan province in China, soil is deficient in selenium.
  • Leads to cardiac problems like myocardial necrosis, cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac enlargement, cardiomyopathy etc
  • Isolated selenium deficiency in other parts of world causes liver necrosis, cirrhosis, cardiomyopathy and muscular dystrophy.

Option C:

  • Iodine deficiency can lead to goitre. Goitre is an enlargement of thyroid gland.
  • It occurs as a part of compensation for decreased synthesis of thyroid hormones (Associated with elevated TSH).
  • It is also due to a failure in auto regulation of T3 & T4 synthesis, caused by deficiency or excess of iodide
  • It is more common in women & with increased age

Causes of Goitre

  • Endemic: in some parts of India (Himalaya belt) & S. Asia & America. This is due to iodine deficiency in the diet. Such geographical regions usually away from sea coast where water & soil are low in iodine content.
  • Relative deficiency during adolescence, pregnancy, lactation etc due to higher requirement which may not be fulfilled nutritionally
  • Goitrogens (Goitrogenic substances) - Substances that interfere with production of thyroid hormones by blocking absorption or utilization of iodine and lead to goitre
    • Include thiocyanates, nitrates, perchlorates, drugs like thiourea, thiouracil, thiocarbamide etc.
    • Plant foods like cabbage, cauliflower, turnip, peanuts, soybeans contain goitrogens (thiocyanates)

Clinical features of Goitre

  • It is usually asymptomatic
  • Enlargement of thyroid gland (neck swelling), Acute pain from thyroidal haemorrhage, Dysphagia (trouble swallowing), Dyspnea (trouble breathing)
  • It may lead to hypothyroidism
  • Severe iodine deficiency during pregnancy and early child growth lead to CRETINISM.
  • It can lead to mental retardation, short stature, hypothyroidism etc

Treatment of Goitre

  • Iodine supplementation, repletion must be done slowly to prevent hyperthyroidism
  • Hypothyroidism is treated with thyroid hormone supplementation
  • Thyroidectomy may be required in symptomatic cases
  • Prevention by iodine supplementation (e.g., iodized salt) in endemic area

Option D:

  • Fluoride deficiency can lead to dental carries.
  • Drinking water containing less than 0.5 ppm of fluoride is associated with development of dental caries in children.

Reference: Lippincott Illustrate Reviews Biochemistry, 8th edition (South Asian edition), Ch 33, Pg 561

questions.text: A 45-year old male, presented with pain and swelling in great toe. On blood investigation, his uric acid level is found to be 9 mg/dl (normal 3.5 to 7 mg/dl). This clinical condition is associated with defects in which of the following metabolism?
questions.solution:
Option A: Gout is a metabolic disorder that occurs due to hyperuricemia. Due to low solubility of uric acid in water, it will get deposited in the synovial joint, leading to arthritis.

Uric acid is an end product of purine nucleotide degradation. At physiological pH, uric acid is mostly ionized and present in plasma as sodium urate.

Uric acid and urate are relatively insoluble molecules which readily precipitate out of aqueous solutions such as urine or synovial fluid.

Option B: End product of pyrimidine catabolism is highly water soluble, so over production of pyrimidine catabolites is rarely associated with clinical disease.

Defects in pyrimidine nucleotide synthesis can lead to orotic aciduria.

Option C: The end product of protein catabolism is urea. Any defect in protein catabolism can lead to increased or decreased urea level in blood. Urea cycle defects can lead to hyperammonemia.

Option D: A defect in phenylalanine catabolism can lead to phenylketonuria.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry, 32nd edition, Ch 33, Pg 334

choices.text: Bind to beta subunit of RNA polymerase to block the initiation of transcription.
Binds to DNA template and interferes with the movement of RNA polymerase along the DNA.
Causes incorrect entry into chain causing chain termination

questions.text: Dactinomycin (known to biochemists as actinomycin D) was the first antibiotic to find therapeutic application in tumor chemotherapy. Which of the following describe its mechanism of action during RNA transcription?
questions.solution:
Option A: Rifampicin and streptovaricin bind with beta subunit of RNA polymerase to block the initiation of transcription. Rifampicin is widely used in the treatment of tuberculosis and leprosy

Option B: Actinomycin D (Dactinomycin) & Mitomycin: Antibiotics from streptomyces. It forms a complex with double stranded DNA and prevents the movement of core enzymes and as a result inhibits the process of chain elongation. They are used as anticancer drugs

Option C: Alpha amanitin: Toxin from mushroom, Inactivates RNA polymerase II

Option D: 3'-deoxyadenosine: Synthetic analog, causes incorrect entry into chain causing chain termination

Other Inhibitors of transcription

  1. Streptolydigin: It binds with the beta subunit of prokaryotic polymerase and thus inhibits the elongation.
  2. Heparin: It is a polyanion that binds to the β' subunit and inhibits transcription in vitro.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews: Biochemistry, 7th edition (SAE), Pg 627

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry, 32nd edition, chapter 36

choices.text: Reduced level of chloride in blood
Reduced level of chloride in sweat
Elevated level of chloride in blood
Elevated level of chloride in sweat

questions.text: A 4-month-old child presented with repeated sinusitis and lung infections. On history it was found that child has greasy, bulky and foul-smelling stool. Genetic study reveals mutation in gene encoding CFTR proteins. Which of the following laboratory findings was expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Cystic Fibrosis Is due to Mutations in the Gene Encoding CFTR, a Chloride Transporter
  • Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a recessive genetic disorder prevalent among whites in North America and certain parts of northern Europe.
  • CF is characterized by chronic bacterial infections of the airways and sinuses, fat maldigestion due to pancreatic exocrine insufficiency, infertility in males due to abnormal development of the vas deferens, and elevated levels of chloride in sweat (>60 mmol/L).
  • It now known that mutations in a gene encoding a protein named cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator protein (CFTR) is responsible for CF. CFTR is a cyclic AMP-regulated Cl- transporter.

So, Option D is correct.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry, 32nd edition, Ch 40, Pg 478

questions.text: CRISPR-Cas9 has revolutionized genomic DNA studies. Which of the following is true for CRISPR-Cas9?
questions.solution:
CRISPR-Cas9 (clustered regularly interspersed short palindromic repeats - associated gene 9)

Option A: RISPR-Cas9 is a novel Gene editing or gene regulatory technique.

Option B & Option C: CRISPR-Cas9 is a RNA-directed site specific endonuclease.

Option D: CAS9 is CRISPR associated protein 9, has an endonuclease enzyme activity which used CRISPR sequences as a guide. Then recognizes specific DNA strands that are complementary to CRISPR sequence & cleave them.

CRISPR-Cas9

It is a novel Gene editing or gene regulatory technique

It was recognized by Emmanuelle Charpentier and Jennifer Doudna (awarded Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 2020).

CRISPR: clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats

  • CRISPR found in genomes of prokaryotic organisms (in bacteria and archaea).

It found in approximately 50% of sequenced bacterial genomes and 90% of sequenced archaea.

  • These sequences are originally derived from DNA fragments of bacteriophages that had previously infected the prokaryote.

Later they are used by prokaryotes to detect and destroy DNA from similar bacteriophages during subsequent infections to prokaryotes.

So these sequences play role as an antiviral (antiphase) defense system for prokaryotes and provide an acquired or adaptive immunity to prevent reinfection of a bacterium by specific bacteriophages

  • CRISPR complements the system of restriction endonucleases and methylases. CRISPR uses RNA-based targeting to bring the Cas9 nuclease to foreign (or any complementary) DNA.

CAS9: CRISPR associated protein 9

  • An endonuclease enzyme
  • It uses CRISPR sequences as a guide (as guide RNA).
  • Then recognizes specific DNA strands that are complementary to CRISPR sequence & cleave them.

CRISPR CAS9

  • Both together are used to edit genes within organisms.
  • Within bacteria this CRISPR-RNA-Cas9 complex then degrades and inactivates the targeted DNA.

The CRISPR system has been also adapted for use in eukaryotic cells, including human cells, where it has been shown to be an RNA-directed site-specific nuclease just as it is in bacteria.

  • It has wide varieties of application in medicine, in basic biological research, food and farming industries.

In medicine, it was used experimentally to treat a patient with a genetic disorder (e.g. sickle cell disease), to treat viral infection like HIV etc.

  • Variations on the use of CRISPR allow for gene deletion, gene editing, gene visualization, and even modulation of gene transcription in basic biological research.

Thus, CRISPR has added an exciting new, highly efficient, and very specific technology to the toolbox of methods for the manipulation of DNA and genetic analysis of mammalian cells.

  • A variant of the CRISPR-Cas system, C2c2, has been shown to site-specifically cleave RNA. This exciting discovery paves the way for potential specific alteration of mRNA levels in human cells.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry, 32nd edition, Ch 39, Pg 435

questions.text: A teenage boy presents with exercise intolerance and muscle cramps during physical activity. He also reports passing dark-colored urine after intense exertion. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
This presentation is characteristic of McArdle disease (Type V glycogen storage disorder), caused by a deficiency of myophosphorylase. Along with exercise intolerance and muscle cramps, patients may also experience myoglobinuria due to rhabdomyolysis, leading to dark, burgundy-colored urine after exertion. This disease is autosomal recessive and often presents in late childhood or adolescence. Muscle biopsy to measure glycogen content is used for diagnosis, and avoiding strenuous exercise is crucial for management.

  • G6PD: Its deficiency leads to hemolytic anemia.
  • Glucose-6-phosphatase is an enzyme involved in gluconeogenesis. It's deficiency leads to von Gierke disease also known as type I glycogen storage disease.
  • Hepatic glycogen phosphorylase deficiency results in type VI glycogen storage
  • Disease/Hers disease.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, pg 167

questions.text: A young girl presents with recurrent acute abdominal pain, tingling sensation in her limbs, and intermittent limb weakness. She also has a history of ingesting paint from the wall of a recently constructed house. Which of the following enzyme defects is likely responsible for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms and history of ingesting paint strongly suggest lead poisoning. Lead poisoning primarily inhibits ALA dehydratase, an enzyme involved in the heme synthesis pathway. This leads to an accumulation of aminolevulinic acid (ALA), causing abdominal pain, neurological symptoms like limb weakness and tingling, and sometimes developmental delays in children.

  • ALA synthase is the first enzyme in the heme synthesis pathway but is less directly affected by lead poisoning.
  • Heme synthase (also known as ferrochelatase) is inhibited by lead but ALA dehydratase is more sensitive to lead.
  • Lysyl oxidase is involved in collagen cross-linking.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is found after being lost in the wilderness for 6 days. He complains of severe weakness and fatigue. His breath has a fruity odor, and his urine test shows positive ketones. Which of the following enzymes is most likely upregulated in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of fruity breath and positive Ketones test indicates the presence of ketonuria, which is a hallmark of starvation ketosis. In starvation, the body shifts to fat metabolism, leading to the production of ketone bodies like acetone, which gives the breath a fruity smell.

During this process, HMG CoA synthase is a key enzyme involved in ketogenesis (formation of ketone bodies) from acetyl-CoA. It catalyzes the first step in the production of ketone bodies in the liver.

  • HMG CoA synthase: Increased during periods of prolonged fasting or starvation to produce ketone bodies for energy.
  • HMG CoA reductase: Involved in cholesterol synthesis.
  • Acetyl CoA carboxylase: Involved in fatty acid synthesis, which is decreased during fasting.
  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase: Converts pyruvate to acetyl-CoA, but its activity is decreased during fasting as glucose is not the primary fuel.

In starvation, HMG CoA synthase is upregulated to sustain energy production through ketone bodies.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Pg 213

questions.text: A child presents with mental retardation, bone pain, and an inability to walk. On fundoscopy, the following is seen, and there is no organomegaly. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The cherry-red spot-on fundus examination, absence of organomegaly, and neurological symptoms such as mental retardation and motor dysfunction point towards Tay-Sachs disease. This is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme β-hexosaminidase A, leading to the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside in neurons. Unlike Niemann-Pick disease, autosomal recessive disorder, caused by a deficiency of sphingomyelinase, which also shows a cherry-red spot but includes organomegaly, Tay-Sachs lacks hepatosplenomegaly.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Pg 235
